label: 014. Emma Elliott Barnwell to Anna Wilkinson -- May 12, 1828
description: In this letter, Emma apologizes for not keeping in touch with Anna since Emma's marriage, and reports that she has traveled frequently, from Beaufort to Charleston to Savannah and back. She also laments the damage done to Charleston by a fire, particularly the destruction of its two Methodist churches.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: Coosaw, May 12th 1828 You shall not think Dearest Anna that in Emma Barnwell-Emma Elliott has forgotten her old-tried & dearest friends--but since marriage, my time has been so fully occupied & cut up by moving from one place to another that I have been prevented (against inclination) keeping up a regular correspondence even with my own immediate family--we have moved up & down to this place three times--paid a visit to one of Mr. Barnwell's sisters--& one to Savannah purposely to see my dear brother William--in which pleasure I was most dreadfully disappointed--owing to a letter written by himself from [illegible] to Phoebe in Columbia, saying that he expected leaving Savannah the latter part of April--her stay both in Charleston & with me was very much shortened--& we hurried on to Savannah much sooner than we either wished or intended--the consequence was that owing to some unforseen delay up the country--Wm was detained & although we remained ten days in S-- we lost the opportunity of seeing him, he had not even arrived a week after we left--Mary I found looking very pale & delicate--but quite happy in her little son Robert who is a sweet little boy quite pretty & what is of more importance[End Page 1] quite well--They all seem quite happy in the prospect of an up country settlement--I hope my dear girls that when Phoebe comes down to pay me a visit--you will meet her here--unless (as report says) you have become so extremely attached to Georgetown that you could not spare even a moment to your friends--indeed dear Anna--as a friend & one deeply interested in your welfare--you might entrust the secret to me--which by the bye seems no secret at all--as a friend to you all I congratulate you on your brother's engagement--for although I am not personally acquainted with the young lady--& therefore know not if it be a cause of congratulation--yet you must all feel happy in witnessing the happiness of your brother (which I take it for granted is very great) as is general on such occasions--& that she may prove a valuable addition to your delightful & happy family is my sincere wish-- Oh my dear Anna what has not poor Charleston suffered by fire--I could have wept over her ruins--& the ruin of so many of her children--but it is cheering to see a ray of hope still beaming amid the general gloom & that ray indicating such promising signs of redoubled seal--& industry for the improvement of the fallen city--surely[End Page 2] her citizens have every reason to expect assistance from on high in their efforts--for their first act was [boring?] in humble submission to the Author of their calamity & then beseeching his powerful arm to assist them in their arduous work the rebuilding of Charleston--The Poor Methodists have shared heavily in the destruction of their papers "the Christian Advocate" is filled with their lamentations for the loss of two of their churches--in it they appeal indiscriminately for assistance from every quarter & "beg for Christ's sake to give money for building a church for the poor & the poorest"--They are so poor that of course the loss falls more heavily on them than others--& as an [illegible] to be sent throughout the states for the purpose of collecting funds--I hope that they soon may build in the general rebuilding-- Dear Anna do write & give me an account of yourself--family & my Charleston friends for it is so long since I have heard from any one from there that I feel almost cut off from all communication with my dear old friend. Where do you intend spending your summer & when do you remove to Georgetown? With much love to Sarah -- & all of your family--I will sign myself Dearest Anna your sincere friend Emma Barnwell[End Page 3] To/Miss Anna B. Wilkinson Care of Dr. W. Wilkinson Charleston So. Ca.[End Page 4]
